title: Eucalyptus rubida
text:
Eucalyptus rubida, commonly known as candlebark, ribbon gum or white gum, is a species of small to medium-sized tree that is <a href="Endemism">endemic</a> to south-eastern <a href="Australia">Australia</a>. It has smooth bark, sometimes with rough bark at the base, lance-shaped or curved adult leaves, flower buds in groups of three, white flowers and cup-shaped, hemispherical or bell-shaped fruit.
Description.
"Eucalyptus rubida" is a tree that typically grows to a height of and forms a <a href="lignotuber">lignotuber</a>. It has smooth, powdery, greyish or pink bark that is shed in long ribbons but there is sometimes persistent fibrous bark near the base of the trunk. Young plants and <a href="coppice">coppice</a> regrowth have <a href="Sessility%20%28botany%29">sessile</a>, <a href="wikt%3Aglaucous%23Adjective">glaucous</a>, more or less round leaves wide arranged in opposite pairs. Adult leaves are arranged alternately, lance-shaped to curved, long and wide, tapering to a <a href="Petiole%20%28botany%29">petiole</a> long. The flower buds are arranged in leaf <a href="wikt%3Aaxil">axil</a>s in groups of three on an unbanched <a href="Peduncle%20%28botany%29">peduncle</a>, the individual buds sessile or an <a href="Pedicel%20%28botany%29">pedicels</a> up to long. Mature buds are oval to spindle-shaped, long and wide with a conical to rounded <a href="Operculum%20%28botany%29">operculum</a>. Flowering mainly occurs from December to April and the flowers are white. The fruit is a woody cup-shaped, hemispherical or bell-shaped <a href="Capsule%20%28botany%29">capsule</a> long and wide with the valves near rim level or protruding slightly.
Taxonomy and naming.
"Eucalyptus rubida" was first formally described in 1899 by <a href="Henry%20Deane%20%28engineer%29">Henry Deane</a> and <a href="Joseph%20Maiden">Joseph Maiden</a> in "<a href="Linnean%20Society%20of%20New%20South%20Wales">Proceedings of the Linnean Society of New South Wales</a>". The <a href="Botanical%20name">specific epithet</a> ("rubida") is from the <a href="Latin">Latin</a> word "rubidus" meaning "red", referring to the seasonally red bark.
In 1991, <a href="Lawrence%20Alexander%20Sidney%20Johnson">Lawrie Johnson</a> and <a href="Ken%20Hill%20%28botanist%29">Ken Hill</a> described two subspecies and the names are accepted by the <a href="Australian%20Plant%20Census">Australian Plant Census</a> as at December 2019:
Distribution and habitat.
Candlebark grows in woodland and forest, usually in shallow soils on tablelands, hills and slopes. Subspecies "barbigerorum" occurs on the <a href="Northern%20Tablelands">Northern Tablelands</a> north of <a href="Armidale%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Armidale</a>. Subspecies "rubida" occurs on the <a href="Southern%20Tablelands">Southern Tablelands</a> of New South Wales, mainly on the northern side of the <a href="Great%20Dividing%20Range">Great Dividing Range</a> in Victoria, between <a href="Halls%20Gap">Halls Gap</a> and <a href="Delegate%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Delegate</a>, and on the tablelands and mountain slopes of eastern Tasmania.
Conservation status.
Subspecies "barbigerorum" is classified as "vulnerable" under the Australian Government "<a href="Environment%20Protection%20and%20Biodiversity%20Conservation%20Act%201999">Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999</a>". The main threats to the subspecies are habitat disturbance caused by agriculture, development and road work and by timber collection.
